bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 23, 1900

div1.p: Reed is delighted to hear about the rain at Keewaydin. He teases Emilie Lawrence Reed and discusses gardening at Keewaydin. He says their son, Lawrence, is impatient for his officer's commission.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 23, 1900
div1.opener:
No. 21,
Have to
wear an
overcoat
down
here!
Camp Columbia,
Quemados, Cuba,
July 23, 1900
Monday afternoon.
My precious oomsey:
div1.p:
Well!
Well!! Well!! so you have
really had a shower at Kee-
waydin? What did you do
to the rain-man to make
him behave so well, lovie,
dear? How about that grass
that was all brown, burnt,
bruised & “busted”? Had to
get Sam to help Jacob
cut it, it was growing
so fast, Eh? well, I must
say that it was a pretty
long while between drinks!
Your sweet letters of the
18th & 19th both came this morn-
ing- I was so sorry that
you and Sis Mottsey have
both been sick- What did
you do that for, lovie, dear?
Did somebody poison the
Mint-bed? Dear me! I
am afraid that your sup-
ply of old Crow gave out
and you and Sis Cyclone
were trying to get along
without any spirituous
Comfort! Send down an
order at once, lovie, dear,
for a fresh supply of “Ta-
rantula Juice” and take
“three fingers” three times
a day before breakfast, &
my professional word
for it, lovie, dear, you
will feel like a fighting-
chicken, instead of having
nausea and such things.
Don't let the supply of
“oh be joyful”get so low
again, sweetheart, or you
both might catch the Mumps!
Didn't I tell you that you
would have a garden
if you would only give the
“thinges” a little time to
grow! Why don't you take
hold of that corn by its
top-knot and pull on it
till it gets tall? Go out
and “yank it silly”, Miss
Farmer-lady! You oughtn't
to let a little patch of
corn
get the better of you in
that way! Put a little
“terpentine” in its ear, and
see if that won't wake
it up! Sit on it, lovie
dear, till it squeals! Kick
it over the back fence!
He! He! I know why that
corn didn't grow, but I
won't tell you till I get back.
It's really too funny, but
one must experiment now
& then! Hurrah! for the
rain at Keewaydin, and hur-
rah for the clematis and
poppies! Give Sis Mottsey
howdy for me, and the same to
Miss Anna Polis! Ha! Ha!
Kiss fat joy for her daddie!
Cool off, lovie, dear, and keep
out of the mud! Love & kisses
for my sweet girls-

div1.opener:
Camp Columbia,
July 24th '00
No. 23-
10 P.M.
My darling wifie:
div1.p:
I have
just read over again your
sweet long letter of July 18th
and your darling short one
of July 19th, and I must write
two or three lines, before
I retire, to my dear little
oomsey who has had such
a time with the hot weather
and the plagued rain-man,
who wouldn't come, and who
just took fiendish delight in
burning up her flowers
and evergreens and her beau-
tiful grass, all except the
roots! What a dreadful
time it must have been!
of course, way down here, where
everything is so green and so much
rain is falling nearly every
day, I couldn't realize that my
precious little Farmer-lady was
having such a dry time at
dear Keewaydin- Had I been
there, I suppose that my groans
would have shaken the very
mountain! Indeed, I should
have been more miserable
than my darling wifie has
been - And then in the midst
of the heat to fall sick with
a pain in one's “tummy”, that
was “the straw that broke the
camel's back”! I don't wonder
that you felt disgusted! You
must tell me all about it
when mantee gets back and
begins to chew on some of
those cabbages and watermelons!
Well, it was just the weather
for the latter! If it doesn't
turn in and rain & freeze for
the next month, we ought to get
some beauties out of that
patch- So you say that the
little evergreens couldn't
stand the racket? Well, we
will just have to try again,
that's all- We can't expect
to meet with success with
every bush we put out-
since the fruits trees & the
vegetables have managed to
hold their own, I shan't com-
plain- I do hope that the
rain will save the black-
berries- We must plant
at lot more next spring:
and some more of those
red raspberries, if my
precious children found them
of good flavor - Look here, lovie,
dear, I am getting sleepy. So
good-night, you sweet joy!
Wednesday morn - 25th. Here we
are, this deliciously cool morning,
in our pajamas and slippers,
after a gorgeous, cold bath!
Last evening, just before I re-
tired, I had a long chat with
Darboy over the phone- He is
very well, but impatient I think
to get at the Philippinos or the
Chinese- He can't understand why
his commission doesn't come
along, but I tell him to take
it quietly-; that he will soon
be studying for promotion- He
will come out on Sunday to see
me- Blest if the mailman is-
n't coming! Love to Aunt Jane
& Helen- Kisses & love for my sweet
baby girls.
